facts.text: Trial commenced on February 11, 1959 on a complaint by the District Magistrate Bahraich.
Charge against the first respondent: sold one tamarind tree to respondent No. 2 for the purpose of felling and removing it without obtaining permission from the competent authority.
Charge against respondent No. 2: felled the tree and removed it.
Offence under s.15(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act VI of 1949.
Complaint transferred from one Magistrate to another till it came on the file of Mr. T. B. Upadhaya who was a Magistrate of the Second Class.
Mr. Upadhaya recorded all the evidence and examined the two respondents.
After recording evidence, powers of Magistrate, First Class were conferred on Mr. Upadhaya.
Mr. Upadhaya pronounced judgment, found respondents guilty, sentenced them to pay a fine of Rs. 50/- each or undergo simple imprisonment for one month.
Respondents filed an appeal before the Additional Sessions Judge, Bahraich which was later converted into a revision.
Additional Sessions Judge made a reference to the High Court recommending that the trial be quashed as the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to try the offence.
High Court reference heard by Mulla, J. who disagreed with Beg, J. in Jaddu and others v. State and Harbans Singh v. State; Mulla, J. referred to larger Bench.
Division Bench: B. N. Nigam and S. D. Singh, JJ. differed; Nigam J. held trial valid, Singh J. disagreed.
Case placed before Verma J. who agreed with Singh J.; conviction and sentence set aside.
High Court certified case fit for appeal to Supreme Court.
Respondent did not appear in Supreme Court appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether a Magistrate of the First Class has jurisdiction to try an offence under s.15(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act, 1949, when s.15(2) specifies that such offences are triable by a Magistrate of the Second or Third Class.

petitioner_arguments.text: There is nothing to prevent the First Class Magistrate from trying an offence under s.15(1) of the Act, because under Schedule III of the Code of Criminal Procedure the ordinary powers of a Magistrate, First Class include the ordinary powers of a Magistrate of the Second Class.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Schedule III, Code of Criminal Procedure

court_reasoning.text: Section 15(2) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act confers jurisdiction to try offences under s.15(1) on Magistrates of the Second and Third Class; if no jurisdiction, proceedings void under s.530 CrPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The words of sub-s.(2) of s.15 exclude jurisdiction of any superior Magistrate.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.28 and 29 CrPC provide that offences under other laws shall be tried by the court mentioned in such law; when no court mentioned, by courts in Eighth Column of Second Schedule.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.15(2) mentions courts (Second/Third Class Magistrates), so s.29(1) excludes Second Schedule; First Class Magistrate excluded.

court_reasoning.text: Schedule III defines general powers of Magistrates and does not create jurisdiction to try offences specified in Second Schedule.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Calling Schedule III in aid would render s.29 redundant.

court_reasoning.text: Reason for restricting to Second/Third Class: conviction appealable, unlike fine <= Rs.50/- by First Class or Rs.200/- summary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intended to confer right of appeal.

holdings.text: Offences under s.15(1) Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act are triable only by Magistrates of the Second or Third Class, not by First Class Magistrate.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held no jurisdiction in superior Magistrates for similar offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harbans Singh and others v. State
precedents_cited.relevance: Beg J. took same view; pointed out appeal reason.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines offence and specifies triable by Second or Third Class Magistrates only.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs jurisdiction: s.29 mandates trial by court specified in special law.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld the High Court's order quashing the trial, conviction and sentence as the First Class Magistrate lacked jurisdiction to try the offence under s.15(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act.

key_quotes.text: The words of sub-s.(2) of s.15 are not rendered ineffective by the prescription of the ordinary powers of the Magistrates.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument based on Schedule III CrPC.

key_quotes.text: A conviction by a Magistrate of the Second or the Third Class... is open to an appeal whereas a conviction by a Magistrate of the First Class and a sentence of fine of Rs.50/- or under... is not appealable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains policy reason for jurisdictional restriction.
